Introduction

Restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM) is the least common type of cardiomyopathy.  It characteristically involves stiffened (and sometimes thickened) ventricular walls that lead to diastolic dysfunction and heart failure.  Common causes of RCM include:



  • Infiltrative disease (eg, amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis)
  • Mediastinal radiation therapy
  • Inherited familial disease


Although RCM causes heart failure in the setting of a preserved left ventricular (LV) ejection fraction, it is generally considered a separate entity from heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).



RCM must be distinguished from constrictive pericarditis, which results from pericardial thickening and fibrosis (eg, following recurrent pericarditis, cardiac surgery).  Features that help differentiate between RCM and constrictive pericarditis are also described in this article.

Pathophysiology



Ventricular wall stiffening is the characteristic finding in RCM.  Usually, both the LV and right ventricular (RV) walls are involved, but clinical manifestations of right-sided heart failure are often especially prominent:



  • Restricted LV diastolic filling leads to elevated left atrial pressure and left atrial enlargement with elevation in pulmonary venous pressures and the development of pulmonary edema.
  • Restricted RV diastolic filling leads to elevated right atrial pressure with right atrial enlargement and systemic venous congestion (elevated central venous pressure), manifesting as prominent findings of right-sided heart failure including jugular venous distension, lower extremity edema, hepatomegaly, and ascites.


Ventricular contractile function usually remains intact in RCM, with reduced cardiac output and heart failure typically fully attributable to diastolic dysfunction, similar to HFpEF (

figure 1
).



The characteristic cardiac chamber findings in RCM are biatrial enlargement and normal or small ventricular cavity size.  For most causes of RCM, ventricular wall stiffening occurs in the absence of wall thickening (normal ventricular wall thickness); however, RCM due to infiltrative disease, particularly amyloidosis, often demonstrates significant wall thickening.



The restricted RV filling in RCM creates specific physical examination findings, including:



  • Prominent y descent of the jugular venous pulse (JVP) waveform (because all filling must occur in early diastole)
  • Positive Kussmaul sign (absence of the expected fall in JVP during inspiration)


These findings are also seen in constrictive pericarditis (described later) because there is similar impairment of RV diastolic filling.

Causes

Infiltrative disease



Infiltrative disease involving the heart is likely the most common cause of RCM.  It typically manifests as RCM early in the disease course and may progress to dilated cardiomyopathy late in the disease course.



  • Amyloidosis:  Most cases of cardiac amyloid are caused by either amyloidosis light chain (AL) or amyloidosis transthyretin (ATTR) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ).  ATTR most commonly occurs in an age-related (wild-type) form, but there is also a less common hereditary form.
  • Sarcoidosis:  Cardiac involvement occurs in a minority of patients with sarcoidosis.  Cardiac sarcoidosis can present with conduction disturbances and/or RCM.
  • Hemochromatosis:  Cardiac involvement is common in hemochromatosis, with myocardial iron deposition leading to ventricular wall stiffening and RCM.

Classic hereditary/familial



  • Gene mutations associated with RCM include those affecting cardiac sarcomere proteins and cardiac desmosome proteins.
  • Idiopathic:  Cases of RCM for which no etiology can be found are generally referred to as idiopathic.  A large portion of these idiopathic cases may be attributable to unknown or poorly recognized genetic mutations.

Mediastinal radiation 



  • Radiation therapy for treatment of malignancies in the region of the chest (eg, breast cancer, lymphoma) can cause myocardial fibrosis that may manifest as RCM up to a decade or more after completion of therapy.  Radiation therapy of the chest can also cause constrictive pericarditis.

Rheumatologic



  • Systemic sclerosis:  RCM is an uncommon manifestation of systemic sclerosis, usually in the setting of extensive organ involvement.

Eosinophilic endomyocardial fibrosis



  • Eosinophilic endomyocardial fibrosis involves ventricular fibrosis that leads to RCM, often in the setting of peripheral eosinophilia.  It is primarily seen in tropical regions of Africa, Asia, and South America.  The cause is unknown, but it may be related to parasitic infection or environmental exposure.

Histopathology



Histopathology in RCM largely depends on the underlying disease process:



  • Cardiac amyloidosis demonstrates cross-sections of normal myocardial cells with other areas of myocardium infiltrated by amorphous and acellular pink material (
    image 1
    ).  Congo red stain classically shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light microscopy.
  • Cardiac sarcoidosis demonstrates granulomas within the myocardium (
    image 2
    ).
  • Cardiac involvement in hemochromatosis demonstrates iron deposits (
    image 3
    ) within cardiomyocytes.

Clinical presentation



RCM may be asymptomatic early in the disease process and clinically presents with symptoms and signs of heart failure (eg, dyspnea, peripheral edema).

Physical examination



  • An S4 may be present in early RCM due to blood striking the stiff ventricular wall during atrial contraction.
  • With more advanced RCM, the typical physical examination findings of heart failure (eg, lung crackles, S3) may be present, but the restricted RV filling in RCM often creates prominence of the following findings:
    • Prominent signs of right-sided heart failure, including jugular venous distension, lower extremity edema, hepatomegaly, and ascites
    • Hepatojugular reflux (
      figure 2
      ), which confirms the presence of a continuous column of elevated hydrostatic pressure in the vena cava and poor capacity of the right ventricle to accommodate venous return
    • Kussmaul sign, which is the absence of the expected decline in JVP during inspiration
    • Rapid y descent (
      figure 3
      ) of the JVP waveform, which is a consequence of restricted RV filling and develops because most diastolic filling occurs rapidly during early diastole


The rapid y descent and Kussmaul signs are also seen in constrictive pericarditis.

ECG



Common ECG findings in RCM include:



  • Evidence of left atrial and right atrial enlargement (
    figure 4
    )
  • Normal voltage QRS complexes (even when there is wall thickening) due to the absence of true LV hypertrophy
  • Possible atrial fibrillation

Echocardiography



The diagnosis of RCM should be suspected based on clinical presentation and is aided by echocardiography showing biatrial enlargement, normal (or small) LV cavity size with prominent diastolic dysfunction, and intact systolic function.  Ventricular wall thickness can be normal or increased.

Additional tests



Additional testing to confirm the underlying cause of RCM include the following:



  • Laboratory testing, including complete blood count, basic metabolic profile, liver function tests, iron studies, and serum and urine protein electrophoresis, is often helpful in suggesting a particular etiology of RCM.
  • Low QRS voltage on ECG despite evidence of LV hypertrophy on echocardiography is suggestive of infiltrative disease, particularly amyloidosis.  This dissociation between QRS voltage and myocardial mass should raise suspicion for RCM.
  • Cardiac MRI with gadolinium contrast is often helpful in demonstrating findings of infiltrative disease and evaluating for disease of the pericardium.
  • Genetic testing is typically reserved for patients in whom the etiology of RCM remains unclear despite laboratory, echocardiography, and cardiac MRI findings.
  • Endomyocardial biopsy is rarely indicated but may be performed in patients in whom the diagnosis remains unclear despite genetic evaluation and other testing.

Differentiation from constrictive pericarditis

Overview of constrictive pericarditis



Constrictive pericarditis (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
) results from thickening and fibrosis of the pericardium (eg, following cardiac surgery or recurrent pericarditis) with adherence to the myocardium and restriction of ventricular diastolic expansion.  RCM is often challenging to differentiate from constrictive pericarditis because the clinical presentation of both conditions is primarily driven by restricted ventricular filling (especially RV filling).

Similarities and differences



Given the restricted ventricular filling, shared features of RCM and constrictive pericarditis include:



  • Prominent signs of right-sided heart failure
  • Hepatojugular reflux
  • Kussmaul sign
  • Rapid y descent of the JVP waveform (Friedreich sign)


History is often helpful in differentiating RCM from constrictive pericarditis:  RCM is associated with infiltrative conditions (eg, sarcoidosis), whereas constrictive pericarditis classically occurs in the setting of recurrent pericarditis, recent cardiac surgery, or tuberculosis (eg, persistent cardiac inflammation leading to thickening and fibrosis).  However, the utility of history can be limited in part because the conditions share some common etiologies (eg, mediastinal radiation).



Additional features useful in differentiating RCM and constrictive pericarditis are shown (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
):



  • Pericardial knock is a high-frequency sound during early diastole that is thought to be caused by a sudden stop in ventricular filling due to restricted expansion of the pericardium.  It is specific for constrictive pericarditis and does not typically occur in RCM.
  • Pericardial calcification is common with constrictive pericarditis but is not expected with RCM.  Pericardial calcification is best visualized with CT imaging, but it can also be evident on chest x-ray or cardiac MRI.  Because the pericardium adheres to the myocardium in constrictive pericarditis, normal sliding of the pericardium over the myocardium, which can be visualized with specialized MRI techniques, can also help differentiate RCM from constrictive pericarditis.
  • Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) is released from the ventricular myocardium in response to ventricular stretch.  Serum BNP level is usually elevated in RCM but normal in constrictive pericarditis because cardiac expansion is restricted by the stiffened pericardium and the ventricular myocardium is not stretched.
  • An S3 is a low-frequency sound created by the abrupt deceleration of blood flow during the rapid filling phase of early diastole and is generally indicative of elevated cardiac filling pressures.  An S3 is common in RCM but is rarely present in constrictive pericarditis.
  • Ventricular interdependence describes a state in which the LV and RV must compete for limited space during diastolic filling, such that the filling of one ventricle is limited at the expense of the filling of the other.  It occurs in conditions in which ventricular expansion is externally restricted (eg, constrictive pericarditis, cardiac tamponade); it does not occur in RCM as there is no external restriction and LV and RV filling remain independent of one another.  Ventricular interdependence is indicated by respirophasic shifting of the interventricular septum on echocardiography.  Inspiration increases venous return to the RV; in constrictive pericarditis, RV expansion is rigidly restricted at the lateral walls and the septum is forced to shift leftward into the LV to increase RV volume and accommodate the increased venous return.  Respirophasic shifting of the interventricular septum confirms constrictive pericarditis (vs RCM).

Management implications



Differentiation of constrictive pericarditis from RCM is crucial because management of the 2 conditions is entirely different.  Management of constrictive pericarditis typically involves pericardiectomy, which provides no benefit for RCM; details of RCM management are presented in the upcoming section.

Other differential diagnosis of RCM



  • Hypertensive heart disease and HFpEF:  Classic HFpEF, which typically develops due to chronic hypertension and contributions from obesity and sedentary lifestyle, clinically appears similar to RCM.  Patients usually have a history of hypertension and other risk factors (eg, obesity, diabetes mellitus), and true concentric (
    figure 5
    ) LV hypertrophy is present with reduced LV cavity size and often evidence of LV hypertrophy on ECG.  Differentiation of RCM from classic HFpEF is important because management differs.
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy can present with symptoms of heart failure but differs from RCM in that LV cavity size (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    ) is increased, LV wall thickness is normal or reduced, and contractile function is impaired.
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can present with symptoms of heart failure but differs from RCM in that there is often asymmetric septal wall thickening and LV outflow tract obstruction may be present.  Wall stiffening is more prominent in RCM than hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Management of RCM



Most of the goal-directed medical therapies used to treat heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and HFpEF have not demonstrated benefit in the management of RCM.  Therefore, treatment is aimed at symptom control and management of the underlying cause of RCM.

Symptom control



  • Diuretics (eg, furosemide) improve volume overload in RCM. 
  • The use of renin-angiotensin system inhibitors (ie, angiotensin blocker-neprilysin inhibitors, ACE inhibitors, and angiotensin II receptor blockers), beta blockers (eg, metoprolol), mineralocorticoid antagonists (eg, spironolactone), and SGLT-2 inhibitors (eg, empagliflozin) is not indicated.  These medications are typically avoided unless warranted for a separate indication (eg, diabetes mellitus).  In general, vasodilators must be used with caution in RCM because they can further impair diastolic filling and precipitate hypotension.

Medical therapy targeted at the underlying cause of RCM



  • Autologous hematopoietic cell transplant (HCT) for cardiac amyloidosis due to AL, or chemotherapy (eg, bortezomib, cyclophosphamide) for patients not eligible for HCT
  • Transthyretin protein stabilizers (eg, tafamidis) for cardiac amyloidosis due to ATTR
  • Glucocorticoids or other immunosuppressive agents (eg, mycophenolate) for cardiac sarcoidosis
  • Phlebotomy or iron chelation therapy for RCM due to hemochromatosis
  • Cardiac transplantation as the definitive treatment for end-stage heart failure due to RCM

Complications



  • Atrial fibrillation is common in RCM due to restricted ventricular diastolic filling causing atrial dilation and stretching.
  • Conduction system disturbances, especially atrioventricular block, are common with RCM.  This is particularly the case with infiltrative disease, which often involves infiltrative involvement of the conduction system.  Such disease also increases the risk for ventricular arrhythmia.
  • Other end-organ damage, including renal failure (cardiorenal syndrome (
    figure 6
    )) and hepatic congestion, is a common consequence of RCM, likely due to the substantial systemic venous congestion that occurs with RCM.

Prognosis



The prognosis for RCM is generally poor, with a high percentage of cases eventually progressing to end-stage heart failure.  Patients awaiting cardiac transplantation for RCM have the highest mortality rate relative to those with other causes of end-stage heart failure, perhaps owing to the limited availability of goal-directed medical therapies for RCM.

Summary



Restrictive cardiomyopathy is the least common type of cardiomyopathy, characteristically involving stiffened (and sometimes thickened) ventricular walls that lead to diastolic dysfunction and heart failure.  Common causes include infiltrative disease (eg, amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis), mediastinal radiation therapy, and inherited familial disease.  Differentiation from similarly presenting conditions, namely constrictive pericarditis, is crucial in the diagnosis.  Although restrictive cardiomyopathy causes heart failure in the setting of a preserved left ventricular ejection fraction, it is generally considered a separate entity from heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, and the treatment differs.  In general, management of restrictive cardiomyopathy is challenging and the prognosis is poor.
